these are kind of general rules in terms
of do I use an exchange house cash
credit these kind of things the first
thing you need to know is it really
depends on the country you're going to
if you're gonna be using cash or card
for example here in Denmark they prefer
you use your credit card but you have to
have a PIN number with it because you'll
have a PIN number they might not accept
it okay so make sure you have the pin
for your credit cards and debit cards
also if you're going to use your credit
cards and debit cards abroad you need to
call your bank and your credit card
company to let them know otherwise they
might block it and I know way too many
people that have not been able to get
any food because their phone because
their credit cards got blocked okay so
you wanna make sure that now in terms of
the best rate sometimes you can find a

like that but in general not all the
times but on average your best exchange
rate you'll get with an ATM okay using
your bank debit card not your credit
card because usually your your credit
card will add fees on to things are
bigger fees international transaction if
you have 3% on purchases is kind of a
typical norm of credit cards not all in
do it but a lot do and your bank usually
doesn't have such high fees understand

like the International rate for that

from Sheila and she'll ask mark can you
tell me what to do about my mobile phone
when I go abroad now probably what could
be your biggest shock surprise horror
story of you're traveling abroad is your
telephone bill because if you don't buy
a data package you don't let them know
you're going abroad you can rack up
hundreds and hundreds even thousands of
dollars of bills on your phone okay
every country in the world you go talk
you can talk to your mobile phone
provider call them home say hey I'm
going abroad what packages do you have
so I use AT&T and they have like a
passport plan so for $30 I get you know
unlimited tech free texts to America a
dollar a minute for phone calls and I
get 128 Meg's of data that's not enough
for me so they have a $60 $120 one
always get the largest one because I use
a lot of data when I'm going because of
work and stuff like that and that one
gives me 35 cents a minute for every
call free texting and I get 800 Meg's of
data and the thing is you really have to
look is how much you guys are going to
use your phone okay because I've seen
people they get the the little package
but then they talk for two hours on the
phone every day I'm like um you're
really killing your budget and the thing
is what really will get you is your data
okay a friend of mine she did me a
European trip she call up her her phone
company I've got the $30 plan went over
her data didn't realize it I mean she's
like 70
she doesn't understand data packages and
stuff like that she racked up a $700
bill because she was posting pictures to
her kids back in the US and she called
up AT&T and they're like sorry since
October 10th of 2014 we will not back
date it and I've had that issue with
them before because we literally had 15
minutes of no coverage in that 15
minutes like we opened up a website I
found out that we were over $15 I called
AT&T talked to them they said they'd be
fine but it still showed up in my bill
so make sure you realize it you can
really get screwed over with your phone
so definitely call get the data package
tell them date you're going to be gone
so you can make get your money that way
or watch out for your phone bills okay
and our third question of the day comes
from Aaron and Aaron is asking about
protests now when you go around you
might see people protesting whether it's
austerity measures in Greece or the
European Central Bank in Frankfurt or
you know Human Rights or things like
this and you really need to be careful
when you are in town where these
protests are look if there's a protest
leave get away from that area because
you don't know what's going to happen is
it going to be safe is it going to get
violent are they going to turn on you I
mean you don't know how it's going to go
so you need to get yourself out of that
situation and I see a lot of tourists
and I'll come like oh we want to go
protest with them all right if you're
going to go do that make sure you're
ready for the ramifications do you want
to get arrested I know the Embassy will
send a lawyer for you that you can pay
for to help you out but do you want to
deal with those kind of things
probably not so you see protests or
anything like that stay away from that
area because it can get scary I mean we
were in Milan and January and there was
a protest that started up there in the
the Piazza Duomo and the Cathedral

there seem to be a lot of people coming
here then all of a sudden literally in
about five minutes
the entire square was full of people and
they were chanting and stuff like that
it wasn't a violent thing but the thing
is like hey I need to get out of this

get out of that situation and if the bad
